DeregistrationReasonOtherText: Facility sold to Chinchiolo Stemilt California.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
FEDERALLY MANDATED RMP SUBMISSION


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Page 1 of 3

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

This facility handles anhydrous ammonia, which is considered a hazardous material.  The properties of  the material make it necessary to observe safety precautions in handling to prevent human exposure and to reduce the threat to the facility's workers and nearby members of the community.  It is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State of California rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the safe procedures used to handle anhydrous ammonia; the safety devices and systems designed and constructed into the facility; and the training of pertinent personnel.

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Anhydrous ammonia is used at Sierra Hills Packing in a refrigeration system to provide cooling to fruit product stored in the cooling rooms of the facility.  The cooling inhibits the ripening process of the fruit and prolongs its shelf life.  The refrigeration system is state-of-the-art technology for the application.  It is computer controlled and has micro processors as part of the control system.  The majority of the refrigeration equipment is located in or near the Mechanical Equipment Room.  The remainder of the refrigeration equipment items are located in the fruit storage rooms and the shipping area.  The ammonia is delivered to the Facility in liquid form and is pumped into a 3,900 gallon capacity High Pressure Receiver.

The receipt, storage, and handling of the subject substance is considered part of a single process.

3a.  Worst Case Release Scenario

The 3,900 gallon anhydrous ammonia is the largest vessel in the anhydrous ammonia system located at the  Sierra Hills Packaging Plant.  The Worst Case release scenario to be modeled for the 3,900 gallon anhydrous ammonia container assumes that 17,172 pounds of anhydrous ammonia is released into the enclosed space of the equipment room and/or

storage rooms.  Rmp*Comp assumes a release duration of 10 minutes resulting in a mitigated relaese rate of 944 pounds per minute.  The distance to the endpoint of  0.14 mg/l for the Worst Case scenario is 1.2 miles.  This anhydrous ammonia release will extend beyond the boundaries of the stationary source.

3b.  Alternative Release Scenario

The Alternative Release scenario for anhydrous ammonia for the 3,900 container located at the Sierra Hills Packaging Plant assumes a release within an enclosed space direct contact with outside air, resulting in an estimated release of 11 lbs.  The period of  release is take to be 1 minute in duration, resulting in a total release quantity of 0.2 lbs/minute for anhydrous ammonia.  The distance to the endpoint of  0.14 mg/l for the Alternative Release Scenario is less than 0.1 miles.  


3c.  Administrative Controls

Administrative controls to limit the distances for each reported scenario exists to restrict to a minimum the amount of anhydrous ammonia released, if a release were to occur, and preferably, to not have a release occur.  These administrative controls are inherent in the operational procedures for the anhydrous ammonia systems and the training provided to the anhydrous ammonia system operators.

3d.  Mitigation Measures

Mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario exists to restrict to a minimum the amount of anhydrous ammonia released, if a release were to occur, and preferably, to not have a release occur.  The mitigation measures are based upon the design, inspection, testing, and maintenance of the anhydrous ammonia system and its related equipment and components.

4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The facility complies with all applicable federal and state codes and regulations.  There are safety meetings and safety training.  The Process Safety Management (PSM) program implemented at the facility for the anhydrous ammonia related

system activities and equipment represents one of the facility's main active commitments to an accidental release prevention program.

5. Five Year Accident History

There have been no incidents involving the release of anhydrous ammonia within the past five years at the facility.

6. Emergency Response Program

The Emergency Response Program is based on alerting personnel at the facility of the need to evacuate the facility and await the arrival of responders from the City of Stockton Fire Department at the evacuation assembly location if a release occurs that causes the evacuation to be initiated.  The San Joaquin County Office of Emergency Services incorporates this response into the County Area Plan for the Region 4 Local Emergency Planning Commission.



FEDERALLY MANDATED RMP SUBMISSION


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Page 2 of 3


7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

There are commitments made under the Process Hazard Analysis element of the Process Safety Management (PSM) that are planned to be implemented over the next year.  Current pplicable codes and regulations are reviewed as a part of the PSM to determine if other commitments need to be made to achieve increased operational safety for the regulated chlorine process system.  These commitments will be prevention and mitigation measures for accidental releases ofthe regulated substance.
